t: Jeremiah 2
Israel Forsakes the Lord
The*p word of the Lord*s came to me, saying,

“Go and proclaim in the hearing of Jerusalem, Thus says the Lord,*s “I*pn remember the devotion of your youth, your*ld love as a bride, how*ln you followed me in the wilderness, in*ld a land not sown.
Israel*ln was holy to the Lord,*s the*ld firstfruits of his harvest. All*ln who ate of it incurred guilt; disaster*ld came upon them, declares*l the Lord.”*s
Hear*p the word of the Lord,*s O house of Jacob, and all the clans of the house of Israel.
Thus says the Lord:*s “What*pn wrong did your fathers find in me that*ld they went far from me, and*ln went after worthlessness, and became worthless?

They*ln did not say, ‘Where is the Lord*s who*ld brought us up from the land of Egypt, who*ln led us in the wilderness, in*ld a land of deserts and pits, in*ln a land of drought and deep darkness, in*ld a land that none passes through, where*ld no man dwells?’
And*ln I brought you into a plentiful land to*ld enjoy its fruits and its good things. But*ln when you came in, you defiled my land and*ld made my heritage an abomination.

The*ln priests did not say, ‘Where is the Lord?’*s Those*ld who handle the law did not know me; the*ln shepherds transgressed against me; the*ld prophets prophesied by Baal and*ld went after things that do not profit.
“Therefore*pn I still contend with you, declares*l the Lord,*s and*ld with your children’s children I will contend.
For*ln cross to the coasts of Cyprus and see, or*ld send to Kedar and examine with care; see*ld if there has been such a thing.
Has*ln a nation changed its gods, even*ld though they are no gods? But*ln my people have changed their glory for*ld that which does not profit.
Be*ln appalled, O heavens, at this; be*ld shocked, be utterly desolate, declares*l the Lord,*s
for*ln my people have committed two evils: they*ln have forsaken me, the*ld fountain of living waters, and*ln hewed out cisterns for themselves, broken*ld cisterns that can hold no water.
“Is*pn Israel a slave? Is he a homeborn servant? Why*ld then has he become a prey?
The*ln lions have roared against him; they*ld have roared loudly. They*ln have made his land a waste; his*ld cities are in ruins, without inhabitant.
Moreover,*ln the men of Memphis and Tahpanhes have*ld shaved the crown of your head.
Have*ln you not brought this upon yourself by*ld forsaking the Lord*s your God, when*ld he led you in the way?
And*ln now what do you gain by going to Egypt to*ld drink the waters of the Nile? Or*ln what do you gain by going to Assyria to*ld drink the waters of the Euphrates?

Your*ln evil will chastise you, and*ld your apostasy will reprove you. Know*ln and see that it is evil and bitter for*ld you to forsake the Lord*s your God; the*ld fear of me is not in you, declares*l the Lord God*s of hosts.
“For*pn long ago I broke your yoke and*ld burst your bonds; but*ld you said, ‘I will not serve.’ Yes,*ln on every high hill and*ld under every green tree you*ld bowed down like a whore.
Yet*ln I planted you a choice vine, wholly*ld of pure seed. How*ln then have you turned degenerate and*ld become a wild vine?
Though*ln you wash yourself with lye and*ld use much soap, the*ld stain of your guilt is still before me, declares*l the Lord God.*s
How*ln can you say, ‘I am not unclean, I*ld have not gone after the Baals’? Look*ln at your way in the valley; know*ld what you have done— a*ln restless young camel running here and there,
a*ld wild donkey used to the wilderness, in*ln her heat sniffing the wind! Who*ld can restrain her lust? None*ln who seek her need weary themselves; in*ld her month they will find her.
Keep*ln your feet from going unshod and*ld your throat from thirst. But*ln you said, ‘It is hopeless, for*ld I have loved foreigners, and*ld after them I will go.’
“As*pn a thief is shamed when caught, so*ld the house of Israel shall be shamed: they,*ln their kings, their officials, their*ld priests, and their prophets,

who*ln say to a tree, ‘You are my father,’ and*ld to a stone, ‘You gave me birth.’ For*ln they have turned their back to me, and*ld not their face. But*ln in the time of their trouble they say, ‘Arise*ld and save us!’
But*ln where are your gods that*ld you made for yourself? Let*ln them arise, if they can save you, in*ld your time of trouble; for*ln as many as your cities are*ld your gods, O Judah.
“Why*pn do you contend with me? You*ld have all transgressed against me, declares*l the Lord.*s
In*ln vain have I struck your children; they*ld took no correction; your*ln own sword devoured your prophets like*ld a ravening lion.

And*ln you, O generation, behold the word of the Lord.*s Have*ln I been a wilderness to Israel, or*ld a land of thick darkness? Why*ln then do my people say, ‘We are free, we*ld will come no more to you’?
Can*ln a virgin forget her ornaments, or*ld a bride her attire? Yet*ln my people have forgotten me days*ld without number.
“How*pn well you direct your course to*ld seek love! So*ln that even to wicked women you*ld have taught your ways.
Also*ln on your skirts is found the*ld lifeblood of the guiltless poor; you*ln did not find them breaking in. Yet*ld in spite of all these things
you*ln say, ‘I am innocent; surely*ld his anger has turned from me.’ Behold,*ln I will bring you to judgment for*ld saying, ‘I have not sinned.’
How*ln much you go about, changing*ld your way! You*ln shall be put to shame by Egypt as*ld you were put to shame by Assyria.
From*ln it too you will come away with*ld your hands on your head, for*ln the Lord*s has rejected those in whom you trust, and*ld you will not prosper by them.
